perturbation.original_text: No later than thirty (30) days following the Closing, each of AWP and the Company shall change its respective corporate name and trade name and cause its organizational documents to be amended to remove any reference to "Armstrong."
perturbation.changed_text: Each of AWP and the Company shall change its respective corporate name and trade name and cause its organizational documents to be amended to remove any reference to "Armstrong" at their earliest convenience.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a specific deadline of thirty days for AWP and the Company to change their names. The modified text replaces this deadline with 'at their earliest convenience,' which is vague and could potentially conflict with state laws regarding required notifications and filings for business name changes. Many states require businesses to update their name and organizational documents within a defined timeframe to maintain good standing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Vague contractual language may conflict with requirements for timely updating of business registration information, varies by state.

perturbation.original_text: (n) "Arizona Trademark License Term" means the period commencing on the Effective Date and ending twenty-four (24) months thereafter.
perturbation.changed_text: (n) "Arizona Trademark License Term" means the period commencing on the Effective Date and ending six (6) months thereafter.
perturbation.explanation: The Arizona Trademark License Term has been shortened from 24 months to 6 months. Depending on the specific trademarks and industry, this could be unreasonably short and conflict with established business practices or reasonable expectations, potentially affecting the ongoing viability of the Buyer's business. This may impact the buyer's ability to use the trademarks in commerce and develop brand recognition.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (potential, depending on context and impact on Buyer's business)

perturbation.original_text: In the event that Arizona declines to institute any Proceedings against third-party infringers or violators of any Arizona Licensed Patents, regarding activities that would fall within the Company Field if conducted by the Company, within forty-five (45) days after being notified or becoming aware of such infringing conduct, the Company or Buyer shall have the right to institute any Proceedings against such third-party infringers or violators.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that Arizona declines to institute any Proceedings against third-party infringers or violators of any Arizona Licensed Patents, regarding activities that would fall within the Company Field if conducted by the Company, within fifteen (15) days after being notified or becoming aware of such infringing conduct, the Company or Buyer shall have the right to institute any Proceedings against such third-party infringers or violators.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 45-day window for Arizona to act on patent infringements before the Company can take action. The modified text reduces this window to 15 days. This significantly shortens the time Arizona has to investigate and decide on a course of action, which may be insufficient for complex patent infringement cases, potentially impacting Arizona's ability to protect its IP effectively.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Unreasonable restriction on patent enforcement rights, potentially conflicting with federal patent law principles.
